text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

SPEAKER 1: don't clean
the classroom for them,
it would be a chaos.

SPEAKER 2: I worked
here for 17 years.

EDGAR VENTURA: This is
something that is not
being done in all the schools.

I can't remember last time
when I went to another school
and I saw blackboards.
I only see whiteboards now.
And computers.
So.

In each classroom we have
a wall full of blackboards.

Each one of them is about
four feet by nine feet.
They're all in lengths of three.

Each blackboard needs to
be cleaned in a certain way
to make sure that--
SPEAKER 2: [SPEAKING SPANISH]

EDGAR VENTURA: A bucket
of water, some towels.

They don't have enough
time in between classes
to let the boards dry by itself.
SPEAKER 1: next class is coming.
Sometimes we're running.

EDGAR VENTURA: We take pride
on everything that we do.

Let us worry about the
cleaning, the setups,

and let the students
concentrate on the studying

and the professors the
teaching, and the staff
to do administrative work.

Our goal is to make
sure that they don't
bother with anything else.

They always have a good clean
place to come in and work.

It reminds me of when I was
in school and professor used
to use chalkboard.
And they used to call us.

I don't think it's something
that should go away.

Every year during commencement
when I see the students

walk across the
stage, and I know

that all of us, we
help them accomplish
what they came here to do.
